bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, November 4, 1922

div1.p: Carter comments on the Health Board's work in Mexico and Grand Bassam.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, November 4, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
November 4, 1922.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose,
General Director,
International Health Board,
In61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
I have no suggestions to make, only to express agreement to
the program outlined by the I. H. B. for yellow fever control for
1923.

The infection at Tampico and Panuco should be eliminated be-
fore January 1st.--probably is now--and if there was no extension
of it beyond these places, Mexico (and hence North America) free
from infection by that date. Still, as there is the possibility
of this extension to fear, Stegomyia work should be kept up long-
er in all key places possibly exposed.

I would be glad to get the data on the alleged yellow fever
case aboard the Burnham. I saw one, aboard the British barque,
Chippewa, developing at my station 68 days out of Rio, with no
history of previous cases aboard. There was no stop en route.
Yet such cases are very rare and this was the longest interval
I have ever myself seen. In all probability the Burnham case
was not yellow fever.
It was reported in July and was pro-

pro-
bably not less than 6 weeks old among them--the whites--then.
The European material is, doubtless, exhausted and diagnosis a-
mong blacks--even if cases are occurring among them--difficult
or impossible.

I have been thinking of the personnel suitable and available
for your two Commissions of Inquiry (C) and (D). For the first--
the Amazon Valley and Caribbean littoral--Guiteras and myself
had been both, but for our earliest--and basic--error in select-
ing our natal days in 1851 and /52 instead of--say--1864 and /65.
However, I am less inclined tempora acta laudare--or should one
say viros actos laudare in this case?--than most old men and do
not doubt but that good men will be forth-coming and that the
program will be carried to a successful end.
